DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

White House Press Secretary Sanders said that Chinese Vice Premier Liu He is to visit Washington next week. (Newswires)


UK

UK PM May is reportedly facing renewed turmoil regarding Brexit options and is said to be under pressure from MPs across different parties to accept EEA membership or risk defeat in Commons. (Guardian)

Dozens of Eurosceptic MPs in the UK's Conservative party are expected to express their frustration tomorrow regarding a lack of direction for the UK's future post-Brexit. (Telegraph)


EU

ECB’s Praet claims that overall an ample degree of monetary stimulus is still required and that inflation is to converge only gradually to target. (Newswires)

ECB's Smets said ECB could take steps to phase out QE this summer but added investors could be right in pushing back forecasts for when the ECB might start hiking rates for first time since the financial crisis. (Newswires)

Italian President Mattarella said that the meetings on Monday showed there was no chance to form a government and a minority government would lead to new elections. Furthermore, Mattarella said he is worried about having an early election in summer and sees a new vote just after December, while he added that he sees possible market risks coming. (Newswires)

Italy's League party said Italy must have a centre-right government or early elections and ruled out President Mattarella's suggestion of a neutral government until the end of the year. Furthermore, Five-Star Movement ruled out support for a neutral government and said elections must take place in July, while Berlusconi's Forza Italia is said to discuss the political situation with allies and is not worried of a vote but would rather have an election in autumn rather than in July


COMMODITIES

UK, France and Germany are close to a package deal to attempt to persuade US President Trump not to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal, according to a senior diplomat. (Channel 10/Twitter)

US President Trump is to announce decision on the Iran nuclear deal tomorrow at 1400ET/1700BST. Furthermore, there were later reports that US President Trump is said to be leaning towards dropping the Iran agreement and re-imposing sanctions according to diplomats familiar with discussions, although reports also added it is unclear if he would moderate a move to scrap the Iran nuclear deal by permitting EU countries to proceed with economic ties with Iran without being penalized by US. (Newswires/NYT)


US

Fed's Barkin (Voter) noted monetary policy is still pretty accommodative but declined to say how many rate hikes he sees for this year. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said there is plenty of stimulus for the economy amid tight labour market and said that the yield curve reflects scepticism regarding medium-term outlook. Furthermore, Kaplan said that the base case remains at 3 hikes total for this year. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures traded with little action before the Wall St open where the thee major indices spiked higher supported by outperformance in the energy sector, amid higher oil prices, with Exxon Mobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP) which sent the S&P 500 in close proximity to the 50DMA at 2679. News that European powers were close to a package deal to try and persuade Trump not to withdraw from the Iran deal then saw energy move lower and stocks in the energy sector pared gains. Tech names also printed a second consecutive day of gains supported by Apple (APPL) which hit a record high for the second straight session, boosted by Warren Buffett increasing its stake to USD 4.7bln followed by positive comments on the stock. SPX +0.35% at 2672, NDX +0.79% at 6822, DJI +0.40% at 24359.

Treasuries were pretty much unchanged for the session with London away from market and in anticipation of the Thursday’s CPI release and ahead of the USD 73bln auction this week where the Treasury will sell USD 31bln in 3yr, USD 25bln in 10yr and USD 17bln in 30yr. Amid thin volume, yields were only mildly higher on Monday with 5yr, 10yr and 30yr up by less than 1bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle half a tick lower at 119.22.

US MARKET WRAP 7 May 2018: Oil pares gains as UK, France, Germany aim to stop Trump pulling out of Iran deal
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities higher, Treasuries down, DXY up, Crude flat.
* REAR-VIEW: UK on holiday, Trump on Iran, Italian politics, Fed and ECB speak.
* AHEAD: China Trade balance, Fed’s Powell to speak, Riksbank’s minutes, earnings from DIS, JD, EA.

 

* GEOPOLITICS: The Iranian Foreign Minister said on Monday that if the US pulls out of the nuclear deal, Tehran's reaction will not be pleasant as the US will have to pay a heavy price. French Foreign Minister reported that France will stick to the Iran nuclear deal no matter what the US does. In later trade, US President Trump tweeted he is to announce a decision on the Iran nuclear deal tomorrow at 14.00ET/17:00BST, note the official deadline was May 12th. UK, France and Germany have said to be close to a package deal to attempt to persuade US President Trump not to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal, according to a senior diplomat.

*FED SPEAK: Fed’s Bostic (voter, dovish) appeared comfortable with ‘some degree’ of overshooting on inflation and reiterated his view for 2 more rate hikes in 2018. Fed’s Barkin (voter) not see outsized wage pressure and inflation is essentially at the Fed's 2% target.  He believes monetary policy is still pretty accommodative. He declined to say how many rate hikes he sees for this year. Fed’s Barkin (voter) said he does not see outsized wage pressure and inflation is essentially at the Fed's 2% target.  He believes monetary policy is still pretty accommodative, but declined to say how many rate hikes he sees for this year.

*ECB SPEAK: ECB’s Praet (dovish, chief-economist) claimed that overall an ample degree of monetary stimulus is still required, inflation is  to converge only gradually to target. He noted the negative surprise in inflation seen for the month of April was mainly due to services prices which were likely to be related to volatile items. ECB's Smets (dove) said the  ECB could take steps in phasing out QE this summer, according to an article published by the WSJ.

*ITALIAN POLITICS: On Monday a  second round of negotiations began in the political space in an attempt to form a new government in the country, after no clear majority was reached at the March 4th elections and after the first consultations between parties failed to establish a coalition. Following the meetings this morning, President Mattarella announced there was no chance to form a government and that a minority government would lead to new elections in July or autumn. In response, Italy's League and  Five-Star Movement  have ruled out support for a neutral government until the end of the year, both urging elections to take place in July. Berlusconi's Forza Italia however, stated he is not worried of a vote but would rather have an election in autumn rather than in July.

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.35% at 2672, NDX +0.79% at 6822 , DJI +0.40% at 24359  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: %, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.89%, Energy: +0.18%, Financials: +0.53%, Health Care: -0.06%, Industrials: +0.56%, Materials: +0.13%, Technology: +0.76%, Telecoms: -0.69%, Utilities: -0.57%.

US Equity futures traded with little action before the Wall St open where the thee major indices spiked higher supported by outperformance in the energy sector, amid higher oil prices, with Exxon Mobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP) which sent the S&P 500 in close proximity to the 50DMA at 2679. News that European powers were close to a package deal to try and persuade Trump not to withdraw from the Iran deal then saw energy move lower and stocks in the energy sector pared gains. Tech names also printed a second consecutive day of gains supported by Apple (APPL) which hit a record high for the second straight session, boosted by Warren Buffett increasing its stake to USD 4.7bln followed by positive comments on the stock.

In earnings, Sysco Corp (SYY) outperformed after it reported a beat on both top and bottom line whilst Tyson Food (TSN) reported a miss on expectations. Dentsply Serona (XRAY) was down more than 6% after a cut of its FY2018 EPS outlook.

In M&A news, AthenaHealth (ATHN) was +25% after Elliot made a USD 160/shr all-cash offer amounting to approx. to USD 6.5bln. Nestle (NESN SW) and Starbucks (SBUX) are to form a global coffee alliance and International Flavours (IFF) is looking to acquire Frutarom for USD 7.1bln. Finally, sources reported that Shire and Takeda (4502 JT) are approaching a USD 64bln deal.

* CRUDE: WTI futures settle USD 1.01 higher at USD 70.73/bbl, Brent futures settled higher by USD 1.30 at USD 76.17/bbl.

Oil prices were higher on Monday for most of the day amid tensions continuing in Iran. Oil pared back those gains ahead of the looming decision on Iran from Trump set to come tomorrow, and after it was reported that US, France and Germany are attempting the US from pulling out of the nuclear deal. OPEC Secretary General Barkindo has called for continued work to preserve the recent gains in the oil market.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle half a tick lower at 119.22.

Treasuries were pretty much unchanged for the session with London away from market and in anticipation of the Thursday’s CPI release and ahead of the USD 73bln auction this week where the Treasury will sell USD 31bln in 3yr, USD 25bln in 10yr and USD 17bln in 30yr. Amid thin volume, yields were only mildly higher on Monday with 5yr, 10yr and 30yr up by less than 1bps.

* FOREX: *DXY: The Greenback has extended gains vs several major rivals and the well known EM currencies that have been on the run of late (ie Lira and Rouble to name just 2), with the index inching up to a marginal new 2018 best in the process, around 92.975. 93.000 is the obvious next target and a clean breach of some similar psychological levels in Dollar/G10 pairings may well provide the impetus.

*GBP: Cable got close to the 1.3500 handle amidst all round USD buying, but bounced relatively firmly again towards 1.3550 as reports circulated suggesting that Japan’s Takeda is close to agreeing a deal to buy Shire (maybe by tomorrow). Meanwhile, EURGBP dipped under 0.8800 as the single currency came under renewed pressure across the board.

*EUR/CHF/AUD: The weakest G10 links and all losing a bit more ground vs the Dollar as EURUSD briefly slipped below 1.1900 after more disappointing Eurozone data/survey news (much weaker than forecast German factory orders, sub-consensus Sentix and below 50 retail PMI) but recoup that level, while USDCHF tested resistance around 1.0050 following a Swiss CPI miss and AUDUSD slipped back through 0.7500.

*NZD/JPY: The Kiwi has pared some of its recent losses to trade back around 0.7000 vs the USD and 1.0700 vs the AUD. USDJPY is flirting with its 10 DMA circa 109.35 that also aligns with a tenkan line, with the aforementioned M&A developments offsetting reported export supply ahead of the Tokyo fix when Japanese participants returned from Golden Week.

*SEK: Firmer vs the EUR (around 10.5100 vs 10.5675 at one stage) and keeping pace with the NOK as Riksbank’s Jochnick reaffirmed guidance for a year end hike, adding that the Krona should appreciate over time and recent weakness is likely transitory.

*CAD: Had been firmer against the USD but reversed course as WTI and Brent declined following the reports that European powers are attempting to persuade Trump to stay in the nuclear deal, however, the pair found resistance ahead of 1.2900.

content:
7th May 2018

Earnings

  • Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp (CTSH) Q1 Non-GAAP EPS USD 1.06 vs. Exp. USD 1.06, revenue USD 3.91bln vs. Exp. USD 3.9bln. (Newswires)
  • Dentsply Serona (XRAY) – Q1 Adj EPS USD 0.45 vs USD 0.42, revenue USD 956mln vs Exp, USD 940mln. The co lower FY2018 EPS outlook, increased its share buyback programme by USD 500mln to USD 1bln. (Newswires)

  • Willis Towers Watson PLC (WLTW) Q1 EPS USD  2.71vs. Exp. USD 2.63, revenue USD 2.55bln vs. Exp. USD 2.17bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) increased its stake in the tech giant to USD 40.7bln in Q1. 68% of its USD 172.98bln fair value was concentrated in American Express (AXP) at Apple, Bank of America (BAC), Coca-Cola (KO) and Wells Fargo (WFC). Warren Buffett said "The best part about buying Apple is that I don't care if anyone talks about buying Apple." Separatel for Apple, executive Cue is to be questioned over a billion dollars Qualcomm (QCOM) patent case. (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA) – The aircraft manufacturer could face order disruption as Eithad Airways is carrying out reviews and changing its strategy, according to a person familiar with the matter. (Newswires)
  • Disney (DIS) - Avengers: Infinity War has won the weekend again after making USD 112.5mln. (Newswires)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – The pharmaceutical released positive results for Phase 3 of esketamine nasal spray resistant to depression. (Newswires)
  • Nike (NKE) – CEO Mark Parker announces changes as he looks to protect the workforce from sexual harassment. (NY Times)
  • UnitedHealth (UNH) – Insperity (NSP) is extending a medical and dental coverage agreement with the medical co. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • American Tower Corporation (AMT) – The co. is to acquire Telkom Kenya's transmission towers by the second half of this year, enabling Telkom to invest in its internet network, the two noted. (Newswires)  
  • CBS Corp. (CBS) – Charlie rose has been sued by three women over sexual harassment. (NY Times)
  • Colgate-Palmolive (CL) – Henning Jakobsen, currently vice-president, was named new CFO. (Newswires)
  • ConocoPhillips (COP) – The co. has acquired the Caribbean assets of Venezuelan PDVSA enforcing a USD 2bln arbitration award in the country. (Newswires)
  • International Flavours (IFF) – The co. is to acquire Frutarom for a USD 7.1bln in cash. (Newswires)
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) – Turkey is looking to retaliate if the US stops to sell weapons and is planning to purchase approx. 100 F-35 Joint Strike Fighter jets from the co. (Newswires)
  • Merck (MRK) - Veeva Systems (VEEV) reported that the drug maker is expanding its use of multichannel Veeva CRM in different markets, including Latin America and Asia Pacific. (Newswires)
  • Navient (NAVI) – Canyon Capital Advisors raised stake in the co. from 7.8% to 9.6%. (Newswires)
  • Starbucks (SBUX) - Nestle (NESN SW) is to form a global coffee alliance with the co. Nestle will pay USD 7.15bln in closing consideration. Companies say transaction does not include the transfer of any fixed assets. Nestle expects this business to contribute positively to its EPS and organic growth target as from 2019. Nestle says the ongoing share repurchase programme will remain unchanged. (Newswires)
  • Wells-Fargo (WFC) – The bank has reached a USD 480mln deal to solve a California class action. Separately, it is looking to hire 20 managing directors this year. Buffett said the co. is 'very likely' to outperform rivals over 10 years, he would consider buying more shares at the current price but he wishes to keep his stake below 10%. (Newswires)
  • Wynn Resorts (WYNN) – Founder Elaine Wynn has commented on the recommendation made by ISS to withhold votes over nominee John Hagenbuch, urging voters to vote for a white proxy card at the 16th May Annual Meeting. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Tesla (TSLA) – The automaker said it may raise more capital to aid a ‘rapid growth’. (Newswires)

  • BWX Technologies (BWXT) – The co. has developed a unique process to produce molybdenum-99 which will be utilised in newly designed technetium-99m generators. (Newswires)
  • Carlyle Group (CG) - The private equity firm. is looking to close its Asia private equity fund at USD 6.5 billion, according to people familiar with the matter, in a deal that adds to the record levels of funds looking deals in the area. (Newswires)

subject: Fixed and FX latest: Bunds fizzling, but Dollar sizzling
content: Eurex volumes have now crossed the 100k mark for Bunds, but the core German bond has not been able to build on best gains beyond 18 ticks and the 159.26 high, as US Treasuries trade down towards overnight session lows. However, the Usd is edging up again and closer to the next big figure at 93.000 having set a fresh ytd peak at 92.974, with Eur/Usd the major pair to wilt and dip just under 1.1900. Tech and positional Eur selling continues, while the fundamental weight on the single currency comes in the form or more Eurozone data indicating a slowdown in growth, and the risk that a seasonally weak Q1 may be dragging a bit further into the current quarter.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 7th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • WTI continues its climb above the USD 70.00/bbl mark, surpassing 4-year highs
  • Equity markets mixed as Nestle announce marketing partnership with Starbucks
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Fed’s Bostic, Barkin, Harker, Kaplan and ECB’s Praet.

**OF NOTE, UK AND IRISH MARKETS ARE CLOSED TODAY DUE TO A BANK HOLIDAY**

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks began the week mostly positive as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s gains on Wall St despite the miss on NFP data, as well as the US delegate visit to China last week which ended with minimal progress although both sides agreed to keep talking. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was lifted by commodity names following recent upside in the complex and with big 4 bank Westpac underpinned after reporting a 6% increase in H1 cash earnings, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) underperformed on return from last week’s holiday closures amid a firmer JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) shrugged off PBoC liquidity inaction to trade in the green and although a lack of progress was made during the US delegation visit, the consensus to keep on talking provided hope that an escalation to a full-blown trade war will likely be avoided. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet and failed to benefit from a subdued tone in Japan, as well as the BoJ Rinban announcement for JPY 840bln of JGBs across the curve with the amounts left unchanged.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3584 (Prev. 6.3521)

BoJ meeting minutes for March 8th-9th meeting stated that the BoJ should maintain easy policy as inflation target still a distance. Furthermore, most members agreed that momentum towards hitting price goal is being maintained and most members also viewed that exports have been on an increasing trend due to firm growth overseas. (Newswires)

 

EU/UK/US

UK PM May is prepared for a backlash from Brexiteers after pushing ahead with her hybrid customs plan. Greg Clark, the Business Secretary, claimed that 3,500 jobs at Toyota could be at risk if the Prime Minister bowed to pressure from other members of her Cabinet and dropped the plans. (FT/Telegraph)

Britain faces restrictions on post-Brexit trade and draconian measures to enforce free-market policies because the European Union fears a future Jeremy Corbyn government, according to EU officials. (Times) 

EU and UK are said to have a list of topics for talks about the future relationship which include financial services, energy, customs and security, while there were also reports that a backup plan to impose border checks on trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK has been drafted by Senior Civil Servants. (Newswires)

Italian leaders are meeting today for a potentially final round of negotiations aimed at forming a government. League's Salvini and Forza Italia's Berlusconi are reportedly divided over the 5 star government offer. Italy’s 5 Star leader Di Maio says the party is not willing to vote for any technocratic government; adding that an early vote is the only alternative if a government cannot be formed (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US National Security Advisor Bolton said US President Trump and Kim Jong Un are to meet in Singapore mid-next month. (Newswires)

Iranian foreign minister says that Tehran's reaction if the US leave the nuclear deal will not be pleasant, and they will pay a heavy price. This is ahead of the decision to be made on May 12th by the US on the Iranian nuclear deal, which the US is slated to be leaving. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities opened mixed (Euostoxx 50 -0.2%) this morning whilst the UK away on bank holiday. Looking at the sectors, IT names are leading with sector-wide gains of almost a percent. Focus today has been more on stock specific stories. SMI heavyweight Nestle (+0.6%) has formed a partnership with Starbucks of which Nestle will pay USD 7.15bln in closing consideration. German insurer Allianz (+0.1%) sold an 8.4% shareholding in Banco BPI (+21.2%) to Caixabank (+0.1%). Elsewhere, Air France (-13.4%) shares fell following the CEO offering his resignation after a pay deal rejection. Furthermore, a French finance minister expressed his concerns regarding the company’s survival. 

FX

DXY

The index has drifted back from fresh 2018 highs made in the aftermath of last Friday’s US jobs data, once the dust settled and markets got over the initial double disappointment of sub-consensus headline payrolls and average earnings. The bottom line is that the latest report is highly unlikely to prevent the Fed from hiking rates a 2nd time this year in June, and the Greenback is holding gains vs all G10 counterparts bar the Pound as a result. DXY currently just above 92.800 vs 92.900 at best ahead of the weekend.

GBP

As noted, Sterling is showing a degree of resilience in UK holiday-thinned trade, with Cable bouncing firmly above the 1.3500 level and Eur/Gbp testing bids around 0.8000 amidst what appears to be a mixture of short-covering and perhaps some bargain hunting ahead of BoE super Thursday. Rate expectations have turned full circle to around 90% for unchanged from tightening only a few weeks ago, but the vote split may still reveal some hike advocates and the minutes could highlight a close call.

EUR/CHF/AUD

The biggest losers vs the Dollar, as Eur/Usd only just retains 1.1900+ status, Usd/Chf extends gains beyond parity in wake of softer than expected Swiss CPI data and Aud/Usd is struggling to stay above 0.7500 amidst bearish cross-winds – note, a major bank has instigated a short Aud/Jpy position around 82.24 and is targeting 80.50.

NZD/CAD/JPY

The Kiwi has pared some of its recent losses to trade back around 0.7000 vs the Usd and 1.0700 vs the Aud, while Usd/Cad has retreated below 1.2900 again ahead of the next round of NAFTA talks  and a speech by Deputy Governor Lane. Usd/Jpy is pivoting around 109.00 after reported Japanese exporter sales on their return from Golden Week and with the 10 DMA circa 109.35 capping the pair.

CNY 

A slightly firmer Usd/Cny mid-point fix from the PBoC at 6.3584, while China’s FX regulator (SAFE) notes that declines in currencies vs the Usd and a correction in asset prices were behind a small fall in its April FX reserves to 3.125 tn from 3.143 tn previously.

FIXED INCOME

The 10 year German benchmark has inched up to a marginal new Eurex high at 159.26, +18 ticks vs -1 tick at worst, and market contacts note that a technical void has been filled in the process (at 159.18). However, follow through buying has been relatively limited so far as volumes continue to be hampered by the May Day holiday in the UK (less than 50k lots traded), and the next upside objective around 159.31 remains intact. Note also, last Friday’s intraday peak is at the base of a further resistance area between 159.39-42 (rising trend-line), while on the flip-side 159.05 is seen as nearest firm support. Conversely, US treasuries remain a tick or so underwater after Friday’s US jobs data and ahead of quarterly refunding this week. More immediately, employment trends for April are due later, along with several Fed speakers.

 

COMMODITIES

Oil continues its climb as WTI maintains its move above USD 70.00/bbl amid reports that Saudi Arabia is looking to push prices up to at least USD 80/bbl (contrary to Iran who see USD 60-65/bbl as 'suitable'). Furthermore, geopolitical tensions remain a key focus for markets ahead of the Trump's judgement on the Iranian nuclear deal on May 12th with non-conciliatory comments from the Iranian foreign minister and president stating that Tehran's reaction if the US leave the nuclear deal will not be pleasant, and they will pay a heavy price.

Movements in Gold are largely being dictated by increases in the USD, with the yellow metal currently down USD 2.00. Copper is seeing strength as a result of Chinese outperformance.

ECB says banks borrowed EUR 14mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 660.359bln; excess liquidity at 1.898tln

Morning EU Movers:  Aker BP (AKERBP NO) +3.3%, Telecom Italia (TIT IM) +1.3%, Nestle (NESN SW) +0.3%, Allianz (ALV GY) +0.3%, Swiss Re (SREN SW) -0.2%, Moncler (MONC IM) -2.7%, Air France (AF FP) -12.8%
Bunds: modest uptick from early lows in paper thin volumes
content: The UK Bank Holiday appears to be weighing heavily on Eurex turnover, with Bunds only mustering just around 11k lots approaching 60 minutes into the session, though the 10 year German debt future has managed to overcome an early wobble and this may in part be due to the unexpected weakness in March factory orders in the absence of anything else. However, this data point does not normally impact and external leads via US Treasuries are mildly bearish so Bunds may not venture too far ahead of the EU cash bourse opens. The range so far has been 159.07-21 vs last Friday’s 159.08 close, with French OATs also firmer having rebounded over the 154.00 level from a 153.90 low and 153.97 previous close in wake of Moody’s outlook upgrade for the sovereign. Ahead, Sentix economic sentiment, ECB weekly QE tallies and a speech from Praet.

**OF NOTE UK AND IRISH MARKETS ARE CLOSED TODAY DUE TO A BANK HOLIDAY**

7th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week mostly positive as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s gains on Wall St despite the miss on NFP data, as well as the US delegate visit to China last week which ended with minimal progress although both sides agreed to keep talking. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was lifted by commodity names following recent upside in the complex and with big 4 bank Westpac underpinned after reporting a 6% increase in H1 cash earnings, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) underperformed on return from last week’s holiday closures amid a firmer JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) shrugged off PBoC liquidity inaction to trade in the green and although a lack of progress was made during the US delegation visit, the consensus to keep on talking provided hope that an escalation to a full-blown trade war will likely be avoided. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet and failed to benefit from a subdued tone in Japan, as well as the BoJ Rinban announcement for JPY 840bln of JGBs across the curve with the amounts left unchanged.

FTSE

Glencore (GLEN LN) – Pact to sell 14.16% stake in Rosneft will not proceed, and the stake is to be transfer to a wholly owned unit of QIA. (Newswires)

Barclays (BARC LN) – The co. has become involved in another mis-selling scandal in relation to loans for solar panels. (Times)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Suppliers to Sainsbury’s and Asda may see up to 2500 jobs at risk if the proposed merger goes ahead. (Times)

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – The co. has agreed a pension deal with unions that keeps the final salary scheme open to members until 2024, and will save USD 196mln over the next 3 years. (Times)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Co. and Liberty Global (LBTYA) are in talks about a takeover of cable networks in Germany, Czech Republic, Hungary and Romania. The deal is estimated to be worth EUR 21bln and are in final stages. It is understood that Vodafone plans to brush aside concerns that its struggling Indian operation could be an obstacle. (The Telegraph)

SSE (SSE LN) – UK’s CMA could unveil this week whether or not it will probs the Co.’s merger with Npower. (FT)

Imperial Brands (IMB LN) – Co. could be considering strategic options such as the sale of some or all of its business amid investor pressure. (Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

First Group (FGP LN) – Investors in the Co. are reportedly looking for Apollo Global Management to make another offer for the Co. (FT)

DAX

Daimler (DAI GY) – Co. says they are cooperating fully in emissions probe. (Newswires)

Allianz (ALV GY) / CaixaBank (CABK SM) / Banco BPI (BPI GY) – Allianz has sold a 8.4% shareholding in Banco BPI to CaixaBank for EUR 178mln. This values Banco BPI’s shares at EUR 1.45, for a premium for 22.67% to the shares closing price on May 4th. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Hannover Rueck (HNR1 GY) – Q1 net income at EUR 273.4mln vs. Exp EUR 245.7mln, EBIT of EUR 433mln vs. Exp. EUR 378.8mln and gross premium rose 17.6% to EUR 5.3bln. Guidance for FY confirmed. (Newswires)

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – The co. booked orders for 68 A320 and A330 aircrafts in April, made 51 deliveries in total, the net orders logged during Q118 was 86 jetliners, overall jetliner backlog to be delivered as of April 30th, totalled 7179 aircrafts showing roughly nine years of production at current rates. (Newswires) 

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France (AF FP) – CEO has offered his resignation after employees rejected a pay deal on Friday. Separately, the French finance minister said the state would not serve as a backstop for the airlines debts, and adds that Air France’s survival is “in the balance” following strike action. (Newswires/BBC)

Atos (ATO FP) – The co. have announced they won a USD 120mln contract for Virginias cyber security. (Newswires)

PAN EUROPE

Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM) / Intrum Justitia (INTRUM SS) – Intrum’s bid for Intesa Sanpaolo’s debt is set to receive approval. (Newswires)

Telefonica (TEF SM) – Co. has retracted a claim (which was made as part of a tariff complaint) for EUR 850mln in compensation from the Mexican government. (El Economista)

Merlin Properties (MRL SM) – Co. are looking to raise up to EUR 500mln in asset sales this year. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

MONCLER (MONC IM) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

SCANDINAVIA

Aker BP (AKERBP NO) – Q1 revenues USD 890mln vs. Exp. USD 888mln and operating profit USD 472mln vs. Exp. USD 449mln. (Newswires)

SMI

Swiss Re (SREN SW) – The discussions with Softbank for a stake in the Swiss co. are reportedly faltering. (FT)

Roche (ROG SW) – The FDA has granted priority review for Tecenriq (atezolizumab), Roche’s proposed lung cancer therapy drug. (Newswires)

Nestle (NESN SW) – Co. and Starbucks (SBUX) form a global coffee alliance. Nestle will pay USD 7.15bln in closing consideration. Companies say transaction does not include the transfer of any fixed assets. Nestle expects this business to contribute positively to its EPS and organic growth target as from 2019. Nestle says the ongoing share repurchase programme will remain unchanged. (Newswires)

US

US Equity futures traded with little action before Wall St open where an initial spike lower was seen as the S&P 500 opened below the 200DMA of 2615 to intraday lows of 2612 before bouncing back and rallying throughout the trading session. The DJIA was lifted by Apple after Warren Buffett said he’d bought a further 75mln shares, taking the stock to its highest level of all time.

EQUITIES: SPX +1.3% at 2663, NDX +1.9% at 6769, DJI +1.4% at 24263.

SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +1.4%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +1.3%, Energy: +0.5%, Financials: +1.3%, Health Care: +0.8%, Industrials: +1.1%, Materials: +1.3%, Technology: +2.0%, Telecoms: +0.8%, Utilities: +0.4%.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian stocks began the week mostly positive as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s gains on Wall St. In FX, the greenback was slightly weaker against its main counterparts
content:
• Asian stocks began the week mostly positive as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s gains on Wall St. In FX, the greenback was slightly weaker against its main counterparts
  • UK PM May is prepared for a backlash from Brexiteers after pushing ahead with her hybrid customs plan
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Fed’s Bostic, Barkin, Harker, Kaplan and ECB’s Praet. UK markets are closed

ASIA

Asian stocks began the week mostly positive as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s gains on Wall St despite the miss on NFP data, as well as the US delegate visit to China last week which ended with minimal progress although both sides agreed to keep talking. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was lifted by commodity names following recent upside in the complex and with big 4 bank Westpac underpinned after reporting a 6% increase in H1 cash earnings, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) underperformed on return from last week’s holiday closures amid a firmer JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) shrugged off PBoC liquidity inaction to trade in the green and although a lack of progress was made during the US delegation visit, the consensus to keep on talking provided hope that an escalation to a full-blown trade war will likely be avoided. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet and failed to benefit from a subdued tone in Japan, as well as the BoJ Rinban announcement for JPY 840bln of JGBs across the curve with the amounts left unchanged.

China proposed to the US it would increase US goods imports and lower tariffs on products including cars as a part of the bilateral negotiations, according to sources. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3584 (Prev. 6.3521)

BoJ meeting minutes for March 8th-9th meeting stated that the BoJ should maintain easy policy as inflation target still a distance. Furthermore, most members agreed that momentum towards hitting price goal is being maintained and most members also viewed that exports have been on an increasing trend due to firm growth overseas. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May is prepared for a backlash from Brexiteers after pushing ahead with her hybrid customs plan. Greg Clark, the Business Secretary, claimed that 3,500 jobs at Toyota could be at risk if the Prime Minister bowed to pressure from other members of her Cabinet and dropped the plans. (FT/Telegraph)

Britain faces restrictions on post-Brexit trade and draconian measures to enforce free-market policies because the European Union fears a future Jeremy Corbyn government, according to EU officials. (Times)  

EU and UK are said to have a list of topics for talks about the future relationship which include financial services, energy, customs and security, while there were also reports that a backup plan to impose border checks on trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK has been drafted by Senior Civil Servants. (Newswires)

EU is said to be considering settling the row over US metal levies with quotas, while there were also reports that the EU are open to a 'limited' US trade deal according to a top official. (Newswires)

Italian leaders will meet today for a potentially final round of negotiations aimed at forming a government. The League has not yet responded to an offer by the 5SM which saw its leader drop its demand to become PM on the condition that The League cuts any ties with Berlusconi. (Newswires)

Moody’s affirmed France at Aa2; outlook revised to positive from stable. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the greenback was slightly weaker against its main counterparts for the majority of the session following the mixed US jobs data. This provided some mild support to EUR/USD and GBP/USD, while USD/JPY briefly slipped below the 109.00 handle. Commodity-linked currencies were kept afloat by recent gains in the underlying complex, although the gains in AUD were later pared amid cross-related flows in which AUD/NZD pulled-back to test 1.0700 to the downside.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were higher with WTI crude futures the forerunner in the complex as it rose to above USD 70.00/bbl for the first time since 2014 amid ongoing geopolitical tensions surrounding Iran, as well as reports that Saudi Arabia are said to be eyeing higher prices this year. Elsewhere, gold was largely dictated by USD-movements while copper also saw marginal gains amid a broad positive risk-tone led by China outperformance.  

Saudi Arabia is maneuvering to push oil prices up to at least USD 80 a barrel this year, in a shift from policy of stabilising the market. (WSJ) However, Iran Deputy Oil Minister Zamaninia said Iran thinks oil output cut agreement will be extended into next year and that prices at USD 60-65/bbl is suitable. (Newswires)

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (27 Apr) 1032 (Prev. 1021). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US National Security Advisor Bolton said US President Trump and Kim Jong Un are to meet in Singapore mid-next month. (Newswires)

US

US yields shifted higher after the Nonfarm Payrolls report, to close the session little changed on the day. The equity surge helped push treasuries lower and the curve saw some flattening with the 2-year yield up over 1.5bps. The pull back also came as markets position for next week’s monster supply, as the Treasury is set to issue USD 73bln in 3-, 10- and 30-year paper next week. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 0.5 ticks higher at 119-22.

US yields shifted higher after the Nonfarm Payrolls report, to close the session little changed on the day. The equity surge helped push treasuries lower and the curve saw some flattening with the 2-year yield up over 1.5bps. The pull back also came as markets position for next week’s monster supply, as the Treasury is set to issue USD 73bln in 3-, 10- and 30-year paper this week.

Fed's Dudley (Voter, Neutral) Said economic outlook looks pretty good; made progress on inflation, while he added that inflation being slightly higher than 2% is not an issue. (Newswires)

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawk) said wage growth is on an upward trend but not picking up fast and that wage growth figures are moderate as are inflation figures, while he also does not see a rapid increase in inflation coming. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said he still expects three hikes this year and could see 2 to 4 hikes depending on data. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said everything he sees tells him there's a little more wage pressure and that best estimate of neutral rate is 2.50%-2.75%, while Fed's Kaplan also stated that the Fed should continue gradually removing accommodation. (Newswires)

Fed’s George (Non-Voter, Hawk) US has attained goals of full employment and price stability for now. (Newswires)

content:
Asia stocks began the week mostly positive as the region took its first opportunity to digest Friday’s gains on Wall St despite the miss on NFP data, as well as the US delegate visit to China last week which ended with minimal progress although both sides agreed to keep talking. ASX 200 (+0.4%) was lifted by commodity names following recent upside in the complex and with big 4 bank Westpac underpinned after reporting a 6% increase in H1 cash earnings, while Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) underperformed on return from last week’s holiday closures amid a firmer JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) shrugged off PBoC liquidity inaction to trade in the green and although a lack of progress was made during the US delegation visit, the consensus to keep on talking provided hope that an escalation to a full-blown trade war will likely be avoided. Finally, 10yr JGBs were quiet and failed to benefit from a subdued tone in Japan, as well as the BoJ Rinban announcement for JPY 840bln of JGBs across the curve with the amounts left unchanged.

Commodities were higher with WTI crude futures the forerunner in the complex as it rose to above USD 70.00/bbl for the first time since 2014 amid ongoing geopolitical tensions surrounding Iran, as well as reports that Saudi Arabia are said to be eyeing higher prices this year. Elsewhere, gold was largely dictated by USD-movements while copper also saw marginal gains amid a broad positive risk-tone led by China outperformance.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia takes cue from Wall St's gains despite NFP miss
content:
Asia stocks begin the week mostly positive as the region takes its first opportunity to digest Friday’s gains on Wall St despite the miss on NFP data, as well as the US delegate visit to China last week which ended with minimal progress although both sides agreed to keep talking. ASX 200 (+0.6%) is lifted by commodity names following recent upside in the complex and with big 4 bank Westpac underpinned after reporting a 6% increase in H1 cash earnings, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) underperforms amid a firmer JPY on return from last week’s holiday closures. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) and Hang Seng (+0.5%) have shrugged off PBoC liquidity inaction to trade in the green and although a lack of progress was made during the US delegation visit, the consensus to keep on talking gives hopes that an escalation to a full-blown trade war will likely be avoided.

In FX markets, the greenback is slightly weaker against its main counterparts following the mixed US jobs data in which headline NFP missed forecasts and unemployment fell to its lowest since 2000 in tandem with a decline in the participation rate. This has provided some mild support to EUR/USD and GBP/USD, while USD/JPY slipped below the 109.00 handle. Commodity linked currencies are also kept afloat by recent gains in the underlying complex in which WTI crude rose above USD 70/bbl for the first time since 2014, although the gains in AUD are to a lesser extent following the recent pull-back in AUD/NZD.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are quiet and failed to benefit from a subdued tone in Japan, as well as the BoJ Rinban announcement for JPY 840bln of JGBs across the curve with the amounts left unchanged.
